awd_titl_txt: AGEP-T: Collaborative Research: Advancing Interdisciplinary STEM Graduate Education in Energy and Sustainability Disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
The Texas A&M University System (TAMU) Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate was created in response to the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 12-554) for the AGEP-Transformation (AGEP-T) track.  The AGEP-T track targets strategic alliances of institutions and organizations to develop, implement, and study innovative evidence-based models and standards for STEM graduate education, postdoctoral training, and academic STEM career preparation that eliminate or mitigate negative factors and promote positive practices for URMs.

The TAMU Alliance is a collaboration between five doctoral degree granting institutions who are members of the Texas A&M University System, to advance URMs around the unifying theme of Energy and Sustainability.   The collaborating institutions include: Texas A&M University Main Campus (TAMUMC), Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMU-K), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), West Texas A&M University (WTAMU), and Texas A&M University Corpus Christi (TAMUCC).  These institutions are engaging the following non-doctoral degree institutions who are also members of the Texas A&M University System:  Texas A&M International University (TAMUI), Texas A&M-San Antonio (TAMUSA), Texas A&M-Texarkana (TAMUT), Tarleton State University (TSU), and Texas A&M-Commerce (TAMUC).  

The vision of the collaboration is to develop an AGEP Alliance that opens multiple paths to the doctorate and professoriate for underrepresented minority (URM) populations by successfully developing and sustaining large-scale, distributed, yet interconnected STEM communities among the diverse Alliance institutions that increase participation, reduce barriers, and promote success of URM doctoral students preparing for careers in the professoriate.

The long-term goal of the TAMU AGEP Alliance is to increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty by measurably increasing the number of STEM doctoral degrees awarded to URM students each year and increasing the number of underrepresented minorities (URMs) transitioning to STEM faculty positions (or to competitive postdocs that lead to faculty positions).

The short-term operational goal of the TAMU AGEP Alliance is to develop, implement and assess a set of transportable strategies to ultimately increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty by increasing the number of URMs who enter participating doctoral programs, the percentage of URMs completing STEM doctoral degrees, and the number who transition to faculty positions (or to competitive postdoctoral positions), and by reducing their time to doctoral degree.

There are four defined objectives for the TAMU AGEP Alliance participants, who are all U.S. citizens, who are URMs in STEM.   The Alliance defines a student participant as an URM U.S. citizen, with a demonstrated interest in energy and sustainability, who is classified as a doctoral or master degree student.  Objectives follow:
Objective 1. Increase the number of URMs entering STEM doctoral degree programs at the five collaborating TAMU AGEP institutions.
Objective 2. Reduce the average time to degree for the TAMU AGEP Alliance URM STEM doctoral students, and increase the percentage of students across the Alliance completing their doctoral degree in five years.
Objective 3. Provide the TAMU AGEP Alliance students with the preparation necessary to compete for faculty positions and increase the number of URMs transitioning from STEM Ph.D. programs to faculty or competitive postdoctoral positions.
Objective 4. Foster TAMU research collaborations to support Alliance-wide collaboration with undergraduate, master's and PhD student researchers that will result in an increase in the number of URM STEM doctoral research dissertations co-advised by faculty from at least 2 partner institutions.

The interventions that form the model for the TAMU AGEP Alliance include: joint institutional recruitment of URM doctoral STEM students; participation of institutions and prospective students in an annual alliance conference; use of regional travel, a virtual social network, and webinars to provide community building and joint mentoring opportunities for AGEP doctoral students; student retention stipends based on level of project participation and timely progress toward degree; student participation in research and professional development training conferences, a mini-grant competition for research seed funding, a learning community, and transitioning activities for post-doctoral fellowship placement and/or faculty positions; and engage faculty in cross-institutional collaborations and partnerships with the NSF-funded Research Coordination Network (RCN-SEES): Climate, Energy, Environment and Engagement in Semiarid Regions (CE3SAR).

The TAMU AGEP Alliance social science research study focuses on two questions related to feelings of inclusion of URM STEM graduate students at each of the Alliance institutions in both experimental and applied settings: 
1) What effect does experiencing isolation or ostracism have on the productivity and progress of URM STEM graduate students and their intentions to continue to the professoriate? 
2) What factors (e.g., institutional, interpersonal, individual) promote or mediate against URM STEM students' experiencing feelings of isolation or ostracism?
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Texas A&M University System - Energy & Sustainability Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (TAMUS E&S AGEP) is a collaboration between five Ph.D. granting institutions throughout the TAMU System aimed at broadening the participation of underrepresented minorities (URM) in STEM disciplines to the successful completion of a doctoral degree and matriculation into the professoriate. The institutions consists of Texas A&M University - College Station (TAMUCS; Research I University and Lead Institution), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU; Historically Black College and University), Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi (TAMUCC; Minority Serving Institution - MSI); Texas A&M University - Kingsville (TAMUK; MSI), and West Texas A&M University (WTAMU; Hispanic Serving Institution).  The proposed program aims to develop an Alliance that opens multiple paths to the doctorate and professoriate for URM populations by successfully developing and sustaining large-scale, distributed, interconnected STEM communities among the diverse Alliance institutions that increase participation, reduce barriers, and promote success of URM doctoral students preparing for careers in the professoriate. The long-term goal of the Alliance is to increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty by measurably increasing the number of STEM doctoral degrees awarded to URM students each year and increasing the number of URMs transitioning to STEM faculty positions (or to competitive postdocs that lead to faculty positions). The short-term operational goal of the project is to develop, implement, and assess a set of transportable strategies to ultimately increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty by increasing the number of URMs who enter participating programs, the percentage of URMs completing STEM Ph.D. degrees, and the number who transition to faculty positions (or to competitive postdoctoral positions), and by reducing their time to degree.

WTAMU used scholarships, dinners, Professional Skills Development Workshops (PSDs), and academic travel opportunities to benefit and engage diverse individuals in interdisciplinary STEM community involvement. Students were awarded a scholarship each semester to help with tuition and/or living expenses. For many of the students, these scholarships were the difference between continuing their education and having to drop from academia. The monthly dinners provided students, their families, and WTAMU faculty time to gather in informal settings to discuss their individual research and goals, while also providing a sounding board for new ideas and new discoveries. These dinners became the catalyst for an interdisciplinary STEM community of mathematicians, engineers, psychologists, environmental scientists, and educators. The PSDs provided opportunities for students and faculty to attend a variety of workshops geared toward improving interpersonal and professional skills, such as providing constructive feedback and communicating effectively in diverse situations. These workshops provided a community of support to help in student life, such as completing a thesis, receiving a grant, and conducting ethical research. Participation in the AGEP grant also allowed WTAMU to provide funding for students to attend academic conferences and workshops. The AGEP grant provided these students with experiences that they would not have otherwise been able to gain. Participation in this grant benefited students, faculty, and staff by creating a STEM community and the associated financial support to aid in the success of their academic goals.

Some successes of TAMUS E&S AGEP include the successful transition of participants to academia and continued interest of some participants in careers in academia. The Alliance utilized four strategies towards meeting project goals: Recruitment, Alliance-wide Fellowship and Research Funding Lab, Professional Development, and Community Building. Alliance Institutions helped fund students to the Southern Regional Educational Board Institute (SREB), an opportunity available that exposes students to what they should be engaged in for preparation for a career in academia. TAMUS E&S AGEP has introduced interventions at Alliance institutions, which have started to reduce the average time to degree for Alliance students and increase the percentage of students completing their doctoral degree in five years. TAMUS E&S AGEP has also exposed Alliance students to conference sessions aimed at preparation to compete for faculty positions and increase the number of URMs transitioning from STEM Ph.D. programs to faculty or postdoctoral positions. TAMUS E&S AGEP has fostered research collaborations to support Alliance-wide collaboration with masters and doctoral student researchers. Fifteen TAMUS E&S AGEP masters students transitioned into doctoral programs, nine graduates progressed to postdoctoral positions and nine graduates progressed to faculty positions.

Eight participants maintained strong interest in the professoriate and joined the TAMU System Research Model AGEP (TxARM AGEP) cohort participants. TAMUCS, TAMUCC, TAMUK, and PVAMU are a part of TxARM AGEP. The second award is a natural succession of the initial TAMUS E&S AGEP award.  A total of 12 students were selected to participate in TxARM. Of those 12, 8 (75%) engaged in the TAMUS E&S AGEP project. Also because of their prior participation in TAMUS E&S AGEP activities, some TxARM participants established a sense of community, which is also evidence of success in nurturing interest in the professoriate.


Last Modified: 03/19/2019
Modified by: Angela M Spaulding
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Texas A&M University System - Energy &  Sustainability Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate  (TAMUS E&S AGEP) is a collaboration between five Ph.D. granting  institutions throughout the TAMU System aimed at broadening the  participation of underrepresented minorities (URM) in STEM disciplines  to the successful completion of a doctoral degree and matriculation into  the professoriate. The institutions consists of Texas A&M  University - College Station (TAMUCS; Research I University and Lead  Institution), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU; Historically Black  College and University), Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi  (TAMUCC; Minority Serving Institution - MSI); Texas  A&M University - Kingsville (TAMUK; MSI), and West Texas A&M  University (WTAMU; Hispanic Serving Institution).  The proposed program  aims to develop an Alliance that opens multiple paths to the doctorate  and professoriate for URM populations by successfully developing and  sustaining large-scale, distributed, interconnected STEM communities  among the diverse Alliance institutions that increase participation,  reduce barriers, and promote success of URM doctoral students preparing  for careers in the professoriate. The long-term goal of  the Alliance is to increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty  by measurably increasing the number of STEM doctoral degrees awarded to  URM students each year and increasing the number of URMs transitioning  to STEM faculty positions (or to competitive postdocs that lead to  faculty positions). The short-term operational goal of the project is to  develop, implement, and assess a set of transportable strategies to  ultimately increase the number of successful URM STEM faculty by  increasing the number of URMs who enter participating programs, the  percentage of URMs completing STEM Ph.D. degrees, and the number who  transition to faculty positions (or to competitive postdoctoral  positions), and by reducing their time to degree.

WTAMU used scholarships, dinners, Professional Skills Development Workshops (PSDs), and academic travel opportunities to benefit and engage diverse  individuals in interdisciplinary STEM community involvement. Students  were awarded a scholarship each semester to help with tuition and/or  living expenses. For many of the students, these scholarships were the  difference between continuing their education and having to drop from  academia. The monthly dinners provided students, their families, and  WTAMU faculty time to gather in informal settings to discuss their  individual research and goals, while also providing a sounding board for  new ideas and new discoveries. These dinners became the catalyst for an  interdisciplinary STEM community of mathematicians, engineers,  psychologists, environmental scientists, and educators. The PSDs provided opportunities for students and faculty to attend a variety of  workshops geared toward improving interpersonal and professional skills,  such as providing constructive feedback and communicating effectively  in diverse situations. These workshops provided a community of support  to help in student life, such as completing a thesis, receiving a grant,  and conducting ethical research. Participation in the AGEP grant also  allowed WTAMU to provide funding for students to attend academic  conferences and workshops. The AGEP grant provided these students with  experiences that they would not have otherwise been able to gain.  Participation in this grant benefited students, faculty, and staff by  creating a STEM community and the associated financial support to aid in  the success of their academic goals.

Some successes of TAMUS  E&S AGEP include the successful transition of participants to  academia and continued interest of some participants in careers in  academia. The Alliance utilized four strategies towards meeting project  goals: Recruitment, Alliance-wide Fellowship and Research Funding Lab,  Professional Development, and Community Building. Alliance Institutions  helped fund students to the Southern Regional Educational Board  Institute (SREB), an opportunity available that exposes students to what  they should be engaged in for preparation for a career in academia.  TAMUS E&S AGEP has introduced interventions at Alliance  institutions, which have started to reduce the average time to degree  for Alliance students and increase the percentage of students completing  their doctoral degree in five years. TAMUS E&S AGEP has also  exposed Alliance students to conference sessions aimed at preparation to  compete for faculty positions and increase the number of URMs  transitioning from STEM Ph.D. programs to faculty or postdoctoral  positions. TAMUS E&S AGEP has fostered research collaborations to  support Alliance-wide collaboration with masters and doctoral student  researchers. Fifteen TAMUS E&S AGEP masters students transitioned  into doctoral programs, nine graduates progressed to postdoctoral  positions and nine graduates progressed to faculty positions.

Eight  participants maintained strong interest in the professoriate and joined  the TAMU System Research Model AGEP (TxARM AGEP) cohort participants.  TAMUCS, TAMUCC, TAMUK, and PVAMU are a part of TxARM AGEP. The second  award is a natural succession of the initial TAMUS E&S AGEP award.   A total of 12 students were selected to participate in TxARM. Of those  12, 8 (75%) engaged in the TAMUS E&S AGEP project. Also because of  their prior participation in TAMUS E&S AGEP activities, some TxARM  participants established a sense of community, which is also evidence of  success in nurturing interest in the professoriate.
